docs.title: Welcome to IntuneGraph
docs.text:
A simple PowerShell script module to upload packages to Microsoft Intune.

  • Made with just PowerShell

    Install IntuneGraph with Install-Module and get started

    Getting started

  • Minimal Dependencies

    Only one dependency, made by Microsoft so the chance of deprecation is minimal

    Dependencies

  • Open Source, MIT

    IntuneGraph is licensed under MIT and available on GitHub

    License

  • Speed

    Because the module can upload directly to Intune without any manual steps it speeds up the process of deploying to Intune

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
The only dependency for this module is the Microsoft.Graph.Authentication Powershell module. Which can be installed using:

Install-Module Microsoft.Graph.Authentication -Scope CurrentUser -Repository PSGallery -Force

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
To install the Module you can either download a local copy by cloning this Git repository or install it from PSGallery.

Install-Module -Name IntuneGraph -Scope CurrentUser -Repository PSGallery -Force

docs.title: Import
docs.text:
After installing the prerequisites the module should be ready to use and can be imported using:

Import-Module IntuneGraph

docs.title: Using the module
docs.text:
To start using the module import it into a script and run:

Connect-MgGraph -Scopes DeviceManagementApps.ReadWrite.All

After connecting you can start uploading to Intune like this:

Import-Module IntuneGraph

$SourceFile = "C:\Path\To\Package.intunewin"

$FileRule = Get-DetectionRule -File -Path "C:\Program Files\Application" -FileOrFolderName "application.exe" -FileDetectionType exists -check32BitOn64System False

$ReturnCodes = Get-DefaultReturnCode

Add-Win32Lob `
  -SourceFile "$SourceFile" `
  -publisher "Publisher name" `
  -description "Short description" `
  -detectionRules @($FileRule) `
  -returnCodes $ReturnCodes `
  -installCmdLine "powershell.exe .\install.ps1" `
  -uninstallCmdLine "powershell.exe .\uninstall.ps1"

docs.title: Adding Microsoft Store Application
docs.text:
On this page you will learn how to add a Microsoft Store Application to Microsoft Intune. To add a Microsoft Store Application the only thing you need is the package Identifier.

Info

The package identifier looks like 9wzdncrfj3tj this can be either capitalized or lowercase like this. This can be found on the Microsoft Store website in the URL

docs.title: 1. Connect to Microsoft Graph
docs.text:
Just like for most other cmdlets in this module you will have to be authenticated to the Microsoft Graph API. To check if you are already authenticated you can run:

Get-MgContext

If it returns some information about the tenant and the authenticated user or application you are successfully connected and can go to step 2. If this returns nothing you are not yet authenticated to the Graph API.

To connect to the Graph API you can run this command for an interactive login prompt. This is the preferred method for testing or ad-hoc commands, if you want to integrate it into a script or CI/CD pipeline it is recommended to use an app registration instead.

Connect-MgGraph -Scopes DeviceManagementApps.ReadWrite.All

docs.title: 2. Upload to Intune
docs.text:
Since the Microsoft Store Applications are already well integrated into Intune the only necessary information for a package is the package Id. Because of this the only thing you have to do to add an application is this.

Add-MSStoreApp -PackageIdentifier '9NCBCSZSJRSB'

If the default information is not what you wanted you can also provide more flags to customize this.

$Params = @{
    PackageIdentifier = '9NCBCSZSJRSB'
    DisplayName = 'Spotify'
    Description = 'Play music using Spotify'
}

Add-MSStoreApp @Params

docs.title: Adding Win32 Application
docs.text: On this page you will learn how to upload a Win32 application to Microsoft Intune. For this we will have to package the application as an intunewin file which is the official way to package Win32 applications supported by microsoft.

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
Make sure you have everything ready before uploading the Win32 application.

  • Win32 packaged as .intunewin file.
  • Install command (if not MSI)
  • Uninstall command (if not MSI)
  • Required metadata
  • Detection rule/Detection script

docs.title: 1. Connect to Microsoft Graph
docs.text:
Just like for most other cmdlets in this module you will have to be authenticated to the Microsoft Graph API. To check if you are already authenticated you can run:

Get-MgContext

If it returns some information about the tenant and the authenticated user or application you are successfully connected and can go to step 2. If this returns nothing you are not yet authenticated to the Graph API.

To connect to the Graph API you can run this command for an interactive login prompt. This is the preferred method for testing or ad-hoc commands, if you want to integrate it into a script or CI/CD pipeline it is recommended to use an app registration instead.

Connect-MgGraph -Scopes DeviceManagementApps.ReadWrite.All

docs.title: Default Codes
docs.text:
In intune the application can request to reboot or report success using the return codes. By default on the web interface it gives you some default return codes which are:

Code Type 0 Success 1707 Success 3010 Soft reboot 1641 Hard reboot 1618 Retry

To just use these return codes you can use:

$ReturnCodes = Get-DefaultReturnCode

docs.title: Custom Codes
docs.text:
If your application requires custom return codes or extra ones you can create those using:

$ReturnCodes = @()
$ReturnCodes += Get-ReturnCode -ReturnCode 1234 -Type 'success'
$ReturnCodes += Get-ReturnCode -ReturnCode 4321 -Type 'hardReboot'
$ReturnCodes += Get-ReturnCode -ReturnCode 22 -Type 'softReboot'

docs.title: 3. Get Detection Rules
docs.text:
For a Win32 application to be available Intune should be able to detect if it's successfully installed or if it is already installed. To do this we need some detection rules, the possible types of detection rules are:

  • PowerShell Detection Script
  • MSI ProductCode Detection
  • File Detection
  • Registry Detection

For your application you only need one detection rule. When you got one you can move on to step 4.

docs.title: Script Detection Rule
docs.text:
For us to use a PowerShell detection script we can save it and it's settings to a variable like this.

So for example I have a detection script called detect-application.ps1 which should run on our client machines as a 64 bit process and doesn't need a signature check.

$Params = @{
    ScriptFile              = 'detect-application.ps1'
    EnforceSignatureCheck   = $false
    RunAs32Bit              = $false
}

$DetectionRule = Get-DetectionRule -PowerShell @Params

docs.title: MSI ProductCode Detection Rule
docs.text:
To get a detection rule based on an MSI productcode we can use this:

$Params = @{
    MSIProductCode = '6f3281c7-acf2-40aa-8cbd-ef3c78a0bd82'
}

$DetectionRule = Get-DetectionRule -MSI @Params

docs.title: File Detection Rule
docs.text:
Another option for detection is based on whether a file or folder exists or not, to do this we can do this:

$Params = @{
    Path                    = 'C:\Program Files\'
    FileOrFolderName        = 'FolderToDetect' 
    FileDetectionType       = 'exists'
    Check32BitOn64System    = $false
}

$DetectionRule = Get-DetectionRule -File @Params

docs.title: Registry Detection Rule
docs.text:
The last type of detection rule is based on a registry key which can be done like this:

$Params = @{
    RegistryKeyPath = 'HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\SoftwareName'
    RegistryDetectionType = 'string'
    RegistryValueName = 'value'
    Check32BitRegOn64System = $false
}

$DetectionRule = Get-DetectionRule -Registry @Params

docs.title: 4. Uploading Intunewin
docs.text:
At this moment there are two possible types of intunewin packages. One is the MSI based one which contains some information about the MSI this one doesn't require any install/uninstall commands.

And we have the more basic EXE/Script version which contains less information but does give more control about the way how to install software.

When using this module the difference between the two is barely noticable, only when you don't provide the install/uninstall commands but on the web interface you have to package it as an EXE/Script type if you want custom install commands.

By default the module will set as much information as possible based on the intunewin file, because of this it's not necessary to set a display name but it is recommended otherwise it will use the name of the intunewin file.

docs.title: MSI Based Intunewin
docs.text:
$Params = @{
    SourceFile      = "C:\Packages\package.intunewin"
    DisplayName     = "Some Software Package"
    Publisher       = "Software Publisher"
    Description     = "Package description"
    DetectionRules  = $DetectionRule
    ReturnCodes     = $ReturnCodes
}

Add-Win32Lob @Params

docs.title: EXE/Script Based Intunewin
docs.text:
$Params = @{
    SourceFile          = "C:\Packages\package.intunewin"
    DisplayName         = "Some Software Package"
    Publisher           = "Software Publisher"
    Description         = "Package description"
    InstallCmdLine      = "powershell.exe -windowstyle hidden -executionpolicy bypass -command .\install.ps1"
    UninstallCmdLine    = "powershell.exe -windowstyle hidden -executionpolicy bypass -command .\uninstall.ps1"
    DetectionRules      = $DetectionRule
    ReturnCodes         = $ReturnCodes
}

Add-Win32Lob @Params

docs.title: Adding Application Logo
docs.text: You now know how to create an application in Intune. The application should work but when distributing software using Company Portal it might be nice to also add a logo to the application. This way the people trying to install the application can see an icon in the Company Portal

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text:
At this moment Microsoft Intune only supports JPEG and PNG images so make sure you have the application logo saved as one of those.

Also make sure you already have an application created in Intune. This can be either a Microsoft Store or Win32 application. For this you will need the application ID which can be found in Intune or as the output of creating an application.

docs.title: 1. Connect to Microsoft Graph
docs.text:
Just like for most other cmdlets in this module you will have to be authenticated to the Microsoft Graph API. To check if you are already authenticated you can run:

Get-MgContext

If it returns some information about the tenant and the authenticated user or application you are successfully connected and can go to step 2. If this returns nothing you are not yet authenticated to the Graph API.

To connect to the Graph API you can run this command for an interactive login prompt. This is the preferred method for testing or ad-hoc commands, if you want to integrate it into a script or CI/CD pipeline it is recommended to use an app registration instead.

Connect-MgGraph -Scopes DeviceManagementApps.ReadWrite.All

docs.title: 2. Add Logo To Application
docs.text:
To add the logo to the application the only thing you have to do is:

$Params = @{
    ApplicationId   = 'a52b9681-ff59-4c69-bfce-8b4d28b56172'
    LogoPath        = './logo.png'
}

Update-ApplicationLogo @Params

docs.title: Assign Aplication
docs.text:
Now after adding the application to intune and optionally adding a logo you can assign the application to users.

To do this there are 3 different options:

  • Assign to specific group
  • Assign to all users
  • Assign to all devices

docs.title: 1. Connect to Microsoft Graph
docs.text:
Just like for most other cmdlets in this module you will have to be authenticated to the Microsoft Graph API. To check if you are already authenticated you can run:

Get-MgContext

If it returns some information about the tenant and the authenticated user or application you are successfully connected and can go to step 2. If this returns nothing you are not yet authenticated to the Graph API.

To connect to the Graph API you can run this command for an interactive login prompt. This is the preferred method for testing or ad-hoc commands, if you want to integrate it into a script or CI/CD pipeline it is recommended to use an app registration instead.

Connect-MgGraph -Scopes DeviceManagementApps.ReadWrite.All

docs.title: Assign to All Users
docs.text:
$Params = @{
    IntuneId    = 'a45fc7ce-d87b-42d7-a6dc-47cb221addd7'
    Intent      = 'available' # (available, required, uninstall, availableWithoutEnrollment)
    AllUsers    = $true
}

Add-Win32ApplicationAssignment @Params

docs.title: Assign to All Devices
docs.text:
$Params = @{
    IntuneId    = 'a45fc7ce-d87b-42d7-a6dc-47cb221addd7'
    Intent      = 'available' # (available, required, uninstall, availableWithoutEnrollment)
    AllDevices  = $true
}

Add-Win32ApplicationAssignment @Params

docs.title: Assign to Specific Group
docs.text:
$Params = @{
    IntuneId    = 'a45fc7ce-d87b-42d7-a6dc-47cb221addd7'
    Intent      = 'available' # (available, required, uninstall, availableWithoutEnrollment)
    Group       = $true
    GroupID     = '6b7f21ed-3475-412f-bc55-128618d38001'
}

Add-Win32ApplicationAssignment @Params

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: This function returns a Win32 application body for the Microsoft Graph API

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Get-Win32AppBody [-MSI] -DisplayName <String> -Publisher <String> -Description <String> -Filename <String> -SetupFileName <String> -InstallScope <String> [-DeviceRestartBehavior <String>] -MSIPackageType <String> -MSIProductCode <String> [-MSIProductName <String>] -MSIProductVersion <String> [-MSIPublisher <String>] -MSIRequiresReboot <Boolean> -MSIUpgradeCode <String> [-AllowUninstall <Boolean>] [<CommonParameters>]

Get-Win32AppBody [-EXE] -DisplayName <String> -Publisher <String> -Description <String> -Filename <String> -SetupFileName <String> -InstallScope <String> [-DeviceRestartBehavior <String>] -InstallCommandLine <String> -UninstallCommandLine <String> [-AllowUninstall <Boolean>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function returns a Win32 application body for the Microsoft Graph API

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Get-Win32AppBody `
    -MSI `
    -DisplayName "$DisplayName" `
    -Publisher "$Publisher" `
    -Description $Description `
    -Filename $SourceFileName `
    -SetupFileName "$SetupFileName" `
    -InstallScope $installScope `
    -MSIPackageType $MsiPackageType `
    -MSIProductCode $MsiProductCode `
    -MSIProductName $DisplayName `
    -MSIProductVersion $MsiProductVersion `
    -MSIPublisher $MsiPublisher `
    -MSIRequiresReboot $MsiRequiresReboot `
    -MSIUpgradeCode $MsiUpgradeCode

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Get-Win32AppBody `
    -EXE `
    -DisplayName "$DisplayName" `
    -Publisher "$Publisher" `
    -Description $Description `
    -Filename $SourceFileName `
    -SetupFileName "$SetupFileName" `
    -InstallExperience $installExperience `
    -InstallCommandLine $InstallCmdLine `
    -UninstallCommandLine $uninstallcmdline

docs.text: This function is used to upload a Win32 Application to Microsoft Intune

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text: Add-Win32Lob [-SourceFile] <String> [-DisplayName <String>] [-Publisher] <String> [-Description] <String> [-DetectionRules] <Array> [-ReturnCodes] <Array> [[-InstallCmdLine] <String>] [[-UninstallCmdLine] <String>] [[-InstallScope] <String>] [-DeviceRestartBehavior <String>] [-AllowUninstall <Boolean>] [-DisplayVersion <Version>] [-Sleep <Int32>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function is used to upload a Win32 Application to Microsoft Intune using the Microsoft Graph API with the only dependency being the Microsoft.Graph.Authentication Module

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text:
Add-Win32Lob -SourceFile "C:\Packages\package.intunewin" `
    -Publisher "Microsoft" `
    -Description "Package description" `
    -DetectionRules @($fileRule) `
    -ReturnCodes $defaultCodes
# Adds a package to Microsoft Intune with just the required parameters, for anything that's not an MSI the installcmd and uninstallcmd

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text:
Add-Win32Lob -SourceFile "C:\Packages\package.intunewin" `
    -Publisher "Microsoft" `
    -Description "Package description" `
    -DetectionRules @($fileRule) `
    -ReturnCodes $defaultCodes `
    -InstallCmdLine "setup.exe" `
    -UninstallCmdLine "uninstall.exe"
# Adds a package to Microsoft Intune with just the required parameters for an exe installer

docs.title: SYNOPSIS
docs.text: This function is used to create new detection rules for a Win32 Application in Microsoft Intune

docs.title: SYNTAX
docs.text:
Get-DetectionRule [-PowerShell] -ScriptFile <String> [-EnforceSignatureCheck <Boolean>] [-RunAs32Bit <Boolean>] [<CommonParameters>]

Get-DetectionRule [-MSI] -MSIProductCode <String> [-MSIProductVersionOperator <String>] [-MSIProductVersion <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

Get-DetectionRule [-File] -Path <String> -FileOrFolderName <String> -FileDetectionType <String> [-FileDetectionOperator <String>] [-FileDetectionValue <String>] [-Check32BitOn64System <Boolean>] [<CommonParameters>]

Get-DetectionRule [-Registry] -RegistryKeyPath <String> -RegistryDetectionType <String> [-RegistryDetectionOperator <String>] [-RegistryValueName <String>] [-RegistryDetectionValue <String>] [-Check32BitRegOn64System <String>] [<CommonParameters>]

docs.title: DESCRIPTION
docs.text: This function is used to create new detection rules for a Win32 Application in Microsoft Intune The options are Powershell, MSI, File or, Registry

docs.title: EXAMPLE 1
docs.text: Get-DetectionRule -PowerShell -ScriptFile detection.ps1 -EnforceSignatureCheck $false -RunAs32Bit $false

docs.title: EXAMPLE 2
docs.text: Get-DetectionRule -MSI -MSIProductCode

docs.title: EXAMPLE 3
docs.text: Get-DetectionRule -File -Path 'C:\Program Files\' -FileOrFolderName 'FolderToDetect' -FileDetectionType exists -Check32BitOn64System False

docs.title: EXAMPLE 4
docs.text: Get-DetectionRule -Registry -RegistryKeyPath -RegistryDetectionType string -RegistryValueName 'value' -Check32BitRegOn64System False
